report_archive_justification: Yes, via GitHub isue tracker https://github.com/racherb/watcher/issues
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No external reports so far, so this is vacuously true.
build_justification: The software is written using Lua, and their implementations run directly on the source code.
test_justification: Yes, it includes a test suite based on tap
test_invocation_justification: Yes. "prove -v ./test/watcher.test.lua" or "./test/watcher.test.lua" invokes the automated test suite.

tests_documented_added_justification: When adding or changing functionality, please include new tests for them as part of your contribution
warnings_strict_justification: The settings for the warning tools are generally fairly strict.
know_secure_design_justification: Raciel H. lead developer, literally wrote the code on how to design secure software
crypto_floss_justification: All required functionality is implemented using FLOSS, including cryptography.
crypto_working_justification: The only cryptographic algorithm directly used by the program is "digest", which is not broken.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: No such vulnerabilities at this time.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: No such vulnerabilities at this time.

name: CPython
description: The Python programming language
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
contribution_requirements_justification: The Python devguide https://devguide.python.org/ explains how to contribute to CPython. It includes coding standard information.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: Python Software Foundation License is a BSD-style, permissive free software license.
floss_license_osi_justification: https://opensource.org/licenses/Python-2.0
documentation_basics_justification: The official Python documentation is located at https://docs.python.org/
documentation_interface_justification: The official Python documentation at https://docs.python.org/ provides API documentation for Python and C/C++ APIs
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: alpha, beta, and release candidates are tagged in git and released at https://www.python.org/downloads/.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_semver_justification: Python does not use SemVer. There are API changes between minor releases.
release_notes_justification: Major changes are listed in the official documentation, e.g. https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.8.html for Python 3.8. CPython also has a more detailed changelog https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/changelog.html
release_notes_vulns_justification: Security fixes and CVE numbers are mentioned in the whatsnew text and in the more detailed changelog, https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/changelog.html
report_process_justification: Python hosts an instance of Roundup issue tracker at https://bugs.python.org/
enhancement_responses_justification: A developer or reviewer usually responds within a couple of hours to days.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati:
https://www.python.org/dev/security/
The page is linked from the footer of every page on https://www.python.org/
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: https://www.python.org/dev/security/ lists the public GPG key of the Python Security Response Team.
build_justification: CPython sources come with autoconf/automake build system and Visual Studio project files.
build_common_tools_justification: CPython uses automake, autoconf, standard C compiler (GCC, clang), and supports Visual Studio.
test_justification: CPython comes with a full unit test suite built-in.
test_invocation_justification: CPython uses the default Python unittest framework to run tests.
test_policy_justification: The policy is documented in the development guide https://devguide.python.org/ and enforced by reviewers.
warnings_justification: The default Makefile enables warnings like -Wall -Wextra and several other compiler specific warnings like -Wno-unused-result -Wsign-compare  -Wno-unused-result -Wno-unused-parameter -Wno-missing-field-initializers -Werror=implicit-function-declaration
warnings_fixed_justification: CPython's C code generally compiles without warnings. Warnings are addressed in new releases.
warnings_strict_justification: CPython enables most C warnings flags (-Wall -Wextra and several additional flags). Warnings are considered bugs and are usually fixed before the next release.
know_secure_design_justification: The Python Core Developer team has several members with security background.
crypto_published_justification: CPython uses OpenSSL for hashing, HMAC and TLS. It only supports widely accepted protocols and algorithns.
crypto_call_justification: CPython ships with fallback modules for some hashing algorithms like MD5, SHA1, and SHA2 family. The code is only used when OpenSSL bindings are not available.
crypto_keylength_justification: CPython relies on OpenSSL for TLS and does not enforce additional restrictions on top of OpenSSL.
crypto_working_justification: MD4, DES, and RC4 are not supported and disabled for TLS protocol. MD5 is available but no longer used except for few legacy protocols like DIGEST auth.
crypto_pfs_justification: PFS key agreement is used by default for TLS.
crypto_password_storage_justification: CPython provides wrappers for OpenSSL's PBKDF2-HMAC and scrypt implementation.
crypto_random_justification: Python uses the operation systems CSPRNG and OpenSSL's DRBG for TLS.
static_analysis_justification: CPython uses LGTM (https://lgtm.com/projects/g/python/cpython), Coverity Scan, and some developers check the C code with clang scan-build
static_analysis_fixed_justification: As of today LGTM and Coverity don't list any errors, only some warnings, recommendations, or false positives
crypto_weaknesses_justification: CPython configures strong, secure defaults for TLS.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Pull requests on Github are tested with Travis CI, Azure Pipelines, and AppVeyor. Additional testing is performed with buildbots (https://www.python.org/dev/buildbot/).
discussion_justification:
GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
Python has a bug tracker at https://bugs.python.org/, mailman mailing lists at https://mail.python.org/mailman/, and a Discourse server at https://discuss.python.org/
english_justification: English is the default language for all documentation, bug tracker, pull requests, and other forms of communication.
crypto_used_network_justification: CPython's stdlib supports HTTPS with TLS 1.2 and newer. It also supports insecure protocols like plain HTTP and FTP if the user chooses to.
crypto_tls12_justification: Python's builtin ssl module supports TLS 1.2 and 1.3.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: CPython verifies certificate and hostnames for HTTPS and recommended SSLContext by default.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: CPython relies on OpenSSL for certificate validation and hostname verification. OpenSSL performs these checks during TLS handshake.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
implementation_languages: Python, C, Objective-C, C++, M4, Batchfile, Shell, Assembly, Makefile, Common Lisp, PLSQL, PowerShell, Rich Text Format, DTrace, XSLT, VBScript
governance_justification: The Python Language Governance is defined in PEP 13, https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0013/
code_of_conduct_justification: The code of conduct for CPython and PSF is https://www.python.org/psf/codeofconduct/
roles_responsibilities_justification: All responsibilities and roles are explained in the developer guide. The responsibilities of Python core developers are explained at https://devguide.python.org/coredev/ and release manager at https://devguide.python.org/devcycle/ . A list of core developers is available at https://devguide.python.org/developers/. Release managers and members of the steering council are listed at https://www.python.org/dev/peps/
access_continuity_justification: CPython has a over 100 core developers. Admin access to repositories and resources is shared across multiple people. https://devguide.python.org/developers/
documentation_architecture_justification: The design, architecture, and core semantics of Python are explained in the official documentation, e.g. https://docs.python.org/3/reference/index.html
documentation_quick_start_justification: The Python documentation has a beginners guide, https://www.python.org/doc/
internationalization_justification: The official documentation is internationalized and currently translated to 5 languages (French, Japanese, Korean, Brazilian Portuguese, Simplified Chinese). More languages are added in the future. https://docs.python.org/
sites_password_security_justification: Python's package index https://pypi.org/ secures passwords with bcrypt. Other subsystems use recommended password KDFs, too.
maintenance_or_update_justification: CPython maintains several older stable versions for several years. The release schedule for every release is describes as a PEP, https://www.python.org/dev/peps/
coding_standards_justification: The coding style are PEP 7 for C code and PEP 8 for Python code, https://www.python.org/dev/peps/. They are references from the developer guide.
coding_standards_enforced_justification: CPython does not automatically enforce styles because it would be too disruptive. Older code does not comply.
build_standard_variables_justification: The configure script https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/configure.ac extends base flags.
build_preserve_debug_justification: The Makefile https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/Makefile.pre.in does not strip debugging information.
build_non_recursive_justification: Python has only one auto-generated Makefile to build the main interpreter.
installation_standard_variables_justific: CPython uses standard  autoconf / automake, which supports DESTDIR.
installation_development_quick_justifica: CPython does not require an installation to run tests.
dependency_monitoring_justification: Release managers and core developers regularly update external dependencies before a release.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: Python uses standard components on Linux and BSD-like platforms. For Windows and macOS the dependencies are regularly updated
automated_integration_testing_justificat: CPython uses GitHub with mandatory CI checks on every pull request.
regression_tests_added50_justification: CPython requires that every new feature and bug fix is accompanied by an automatic regression test.
test_statement_coverage80_justification: CPython uses several tools to automatically measure code coverage. Code coverage is currently around 82%, https://codecov.io/gh/python/cpython
test_policy_mandated_justification: The formal policy is part of the pull request workflow documentation, https://devguide.python.org/pullrequest
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: CPython includes SHA2 family, SHA3 family, and Blake2. Further more it supports several algorithms that are supported by OpenSSL.
signed_releases_justification: Releases are signed with the release manager's personal GPG key, see https://www.python.org/downloads/
version_tags_signed_justification: Release tags are signed with the personal GPG key of the release manager.

name: TestableHttpClient
description: A simple library to make testing with HttpClient and related classes easier
description_good_justification:
https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/

Although a website other than the github project page might be prefered.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification:
This should be met by the pull request template, although it might be more useful to add this in the normal documentation for better referencing.
https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/blob/master/.github/pull_request_template.md
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/blob/master/LICENSE.md>.
floss_license_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
documentation_interface_justification:
There is documentation on the API itself, which is visible in most IDE's. Besides that the API should be relatively self explanatory. 
Examples can be found in the IntegrationTest project.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Repository in GitHub is the only repository for this project, all changes are tracked by git.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There are no known vulnerabilities yet.
report_tracker_justification: The GitHub issue tracker is used: https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/issues
report_process_justification:
This is described in the contribution document and in the github templates.

https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: There are no vulnerability reports yet.
build_justification: The project is build by using standard dotnet tooling.
build_common_tools_justification: The library is build using the dotnet tooling and tested using XUnit
build_floss_tools_justification: The dotnet tooling and XUnit is OpenSource
test_justification: Every library has it's own Test project and an integrationtest project is also available all placed in the folder 'test': https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/tree/master/test
test_invocation_justification: All test can be run using `dotnet test`: https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/actions?query=workflow%3ACI
test_most_justification: Allthough there is no prove for this yet, the project is created using a test first approach.
test_policy_justification: This polict is documented in our CONTRIBUTING.md
tests_are_added_justification: All Pull Requests have changes in tests.
tests_documented_added_justification: This is documented in our CONTRIBUTING.md: https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md and the PR template.
warnings_justification: Compiler warnings are turned on and extra code analyzers are added.
warnings_fixed_justification: During reviews the code is checked for warnings and a comment is given when warnings are not addressed.
warnings_strict_justification: Although warnings are not shown as errors, they are registered by SonarQube and this will prevent PR's to be merged.
delivery_mitm_justification:
Packages can only be downloaded via NuGet, which only supports https.
Source code is only downloadable from GitHub, which only supports https.
static_analysis_justification: FxCopAnalyzer and SonarQube are used in the CI pipeline
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: SonarQube is used in the CI pipeline: https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=dnperfors_TestableHttpClient
static_analysis_fixed_justification: vulnerabilities discovered by static code analysis in dotnet will result in a warnings or errors, which are solved immediately.
static_analysis_often_justification: Static code analysis is performed with every build, locally and on the server.
dynamic_analysis_justification: Dynamic analysis tools don't seem to be very useful in the scope of a library that is only used during unittesting.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: TestableHttpClient is written using .NET and doesn't use any memory-unsafe functionality.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio:
CI is provided by GitHub Workflow, which builds every commit on the repository, but also every Pull Request.
https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/actions?query=workflow%3ACI
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: All project information is in English, code comments are written in English.
hardening_justification: This library is intended to be used in unittests
crypto_used_network_justification: This library isn't responsible for network communications.
crypto_tls12_justification: This library isn't responsible for TLS support.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: This library isn't responsible for TLS support.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: This library isn't responsible for TLS support.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers. https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient
installation_common_justification: NuGet packages are provided which perform the installation
build_reproducible_justification: The CI is responsible for this: https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/actions?query=workflow%3ACI
documentation_architecture_justification: The component is a library with a single responsibility, it doesn't contain a describable architecture like a program.
documentation_quick_start_justification: The "quick start" guide is provided in the README.md: https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/blob/master/README.md
documentation_current_justification: This is generally checked and addressed during reviews.
internationalization_justification: The library does produce error messages, but these are for developers only and we assume that every developer knows enough English.
maintenance_or_update_justification: Versions are backwards compatible and follow the semver standard.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: There has been no vulnerabilities reported yet.
coding_standards_justification: Coding standards are enforced using the .editorconfig: https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/blob/master/.editorconfig
coding_standards_enforced_justification: dotnet build issues warnings when code doesn't follow the guidelines specified in the .editorconfig. Besides that the CI pipeline runs dotnet format to ensure that formatting is correct as well.
build_standard_variables_justification: Only .NET assemblies are generated which are not native.
build_preserve_debug_justification: This is part of the default build system of .NET. The provide packages have debug information and sourcelink support.
build_non_recursive_justification: Only projects that are specified in the solution are build.
build_repeatable_justification: The build pipeline is specified in Git and is repeatable.
installation_development_quick_justifica: Project can easily be setup using the dotnet cli.
external_dependencies_justification:
The list of requirements are listed by nuget:
https://www.nuget.org/packages/testablehttpclient
https://www.nuget.org/packages/testablehttpclient.nfluent
dependency_monitoring_justification: We make use of GitHubs dependabot: https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/network/alerts
updateable_reused_components_justificati: The NuGet package manager is used.
interfaces_current_justification: TestableHttpClient is build on top of the .NET stack, which in itself is open source.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: The CI runs all the tests for every build. The build will fail whenever (one of) the tests fails.
regression_tests_added50_justification: Currently no bugs have been reported/fixed, since we are still in an early stage of development. However, since we are working with PullRequests, the reviewer will check that tests are added for a bug.
test_statement_coverage80_justification:
Coverlet is used during test run and SonarQube reports the coverage: https://sonarcloud.io/component_measures?id=dnperfors_TestableHttpClient&metric=coverage&view=list
By default SonarQube will prevent merging PR's when the coverage is under 80%
test_policy_mandated_justification: This is documented in our CONTRIBUTING.md: https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
implement_secure_design_justification: The library is designed to save data in memory, as it comes in.
input_validation_justification: This library is not intended to be used in production environments, but for use in unittests, therefore it doesn't have untrusted sources.
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: There is no cryptography support in the library
crypto_credential_agility_justification: Authentication credentials en cryptographic keys are not processed in this library.
signed_releases_justification: Ultimately the nuget package should be signed, however, we don't have the resources and the knowledge yet to do this.
version_tags_signed_justification: By creating tags in GitHub, the tags are automatically cryptographically signed. However it might be better to use developer GPG keys instead.
small_tasks_justification: Issues that can be picked up by new contributors are marked with "good first issue": https://github.com/dnperfors/TestableHttpClient/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22good+first+issue%22
two_person_review_justification: There is currently only a single contributer
security_review_justification: Not done yet, will be done before first release.

name: druzhba
description:
Druzhba is a friendly framework for building data pipelines. It efficiently copies data from your production/transactional databases to your data warehouse.

A Druzhba pipeline connects one or more source databases to a target database. It pulls data incrementally from each configured source table and writes to a target table (which is automatically created in most cases), tracking incremental state and history in the target database. Druzhba may also be configured to pull using custom SQL, which supports Jinja templating of pipeline metadata.

In a typical deployment, Druzhba serves the extract and load steps of an ELT pipeline, although it is capable of limited in-flight transformations through custom extract SQL.
interact_justification: https://github.com/seatgeek/druzhba/issues as stated on both GitHub readme and docs cover page
contribution_justification:
Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.

See also: https://druzhba.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contributing.html
contribution_requirements_justification: We request using an included set of code quality tools as described at https://druzhba.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contributing.html
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/seatgeek/druzhba/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
Some documentation basics file contents found.

Built docs hosted at https://druzhba.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_semver_justification: Druzhba uses a slightly modified version of SemVar described at https://github.com/seatgeek/druzhba/blob/master/docs/release.rst#versioning-system that project maintainers believe better fits Duzhba's execution model.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There are currently no publicly known vulnerabilities
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: Contained in the readme at https://github.com/seatgeek/druzhba and the docs at https://druzhba.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: Contained in the readme at https://github.com/seatgeek/druzhba and the docs at https://druzhba.readthedocs.io/en/latest/. There is an option to open a public issue and email sensitive information to the maintainers. Email supports TLS.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: There are currently no reported vulnerabilities.
test_justification: Unit test suite is run by Nose which is licensed LGPL. There is also an integration test suite that requires special equipment.
test_most_justification: There is extensive unit and integration testing, but we do not currently have an automated coverage report.
test_policy_justification: Informal policy and added to the docs
tests_are_added_justification: Tests are maintained in the same source control repository as the application source so a new feature's pull request will show both changes to the application code and the test suite.
warnings_strict_justification: We reject code change with pylint errors or warnings. We use black for code formatting so disable style conventions in pylint.
crypto_published_justification: Druzhba does not implement cryptographic protocols
crypto_keylength_justification: We don't currently set any key lengths nor verify them for ssl mode in odbc connections. We should probably support sslmode=require at a minimum.
delivery_mitm_justification: Source code can be downloaded from GitLab with https or git+ssh. Packages can be downloaded from https://pypi.org/project/druzhba/#files with https.
delivery_unsigned_justification: Cryptographic hashes are not distributed by http
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: There are no known unpatched vulnerabilities at this time
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: There are no known unpatched vulnerabilities at this time
static_analysis_justification: Release instructions specify to run bandit before release.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Release instructions specify to run bandit before release.
static_analysis_often_justification: The nature of druzhba will cause bandit to flag a large number of sql statements that need to be manually examined.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Python is a managed memory language
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Our unit tests check runtime assertions but we do not use a dynamic analysis tool
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: Currently all documentation is in English and the GitHub issue tracker is monitored by English speakers
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
build_preserve_debug_justification: Python application with no build system
build_non_recursive_justification: Python application with no build system
crypto_credential_agility_justification: Passwords may be passed through environment variables and keys are read from external files.
